answers: When scheduling a job to
you are shipping both the function name and the parameters. The child process receives the function names and looks it up within its memory.
As you are passing an object method, things get more complicated. The child process cannot find such method among its functions. Therefore, the parent has to pickle and ship the whole object.
This is where you encounter the problem:
The pickle protocol does not know how to serialize your object as it contains un-picklable components. In particular,
is an internal Python data structure.

It is recommended against passing object methods to process pools as it's hard to predict whether an object will be picklable or not. Moreover, you pay the increased cost of serializing an entire object and transferring it through a pipe instead of just shipping the function name.
For more information regarding what is easy to pickle and what is not you can refer to its module
If you cannot comply with the above recommendation, you can have a look at other pickle implementations such as

question: Why does a simple C++ program generate so many branch commands? Using perf on Linux [duplicate]
details: I must be doing something stupid or using
incorrectly ?
Compile command (Using g++-9.2.1)
Following the

stat            Run a command and gather performance counter
statistics
I attempted
And in the output
The question is why? should I "clean" the registers before running this command? is this normal?
answers: About 80% of the branching comes from dynamic linking. Files need to be opened and then the dynamic libraries need to be parsed. This requires a lot of decision making as the contents of the file have to be tested to see what their format is, what sections they have, and so on.

Most of the remaining 20% is precisely that same kind of logic operating on the executable. It has a complex format and code has to parse that format to figure out what sections it has, find the endings of each section, and decide how to lay them out in memory before the program begins executing.

A good start point is to always use assertions and to validate inputs. You may even want to use code contracts. When something went wrong and you can't figure out what happens with a quick look at your code then you have to resort to an old friend:

If this happens in production then you'd better to add assertions in incriminated code, probably we won't see in your code what you can't see by yourself (but you can always bet).

question: Meaning of the Dollar symbol ($) in the log messages
details:
Sometime in log output after a class name there is a Dollor symbol ($) in the message what does that mean? I thought it's the method name or the variable name in the class that caused the exception but in this case it doesn't make sense (SessionsFragment$4 it can't be the name of a method or variable).
so what is it ?
answers: The
is a separator that indicates that there is a nested class
inside the
class, and that there is an anonymous inner class (the fourth one, it looks like) inside the
class.
the
separator.

The nested classes are distinguished from the higher-level nested classes and from the top-level class by using the dollar sign character ($). So, technically, the "simple" name of the second nested class is StackTrace$FirstNested$SecondNested.

to the price of the i-th jacket. The third line contains M

The Output:
